Award.AwardTitle: Diffusion Models for Performance Analysis of Large-Scale Service Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Stochastic processing networks have been used to model large-scale service systems including customer contact centers and hospital operations. Due to the complexity of a stochastic processing network, it is often difficult or impossible to compute its performance measures in a timely manner. Diffusion models offer efficient approximations for various classes of stochastic processing networks. If successful, the research will contribute to the creation of new analytical tools for accurate staffing and quality customer service at customer contact centers. It will also contribute to the creation of analytical tools for hospital inpatient flow management.

The research will establish convergence rates of steady-state diffusion approximations. The established convergence rates guarantee the accuracy of the steady-state diffusion approximation of a stochastic processing network with given system parameters, which are not necessarily going to any limit. The PI plans to fully develop a framework that is based on Stein's method to prove the convergence rates. The framework currently has four components: Poisson equations and gradient bounds, generator coupling, state space collapse, and moment bounds. The framework, with possible addition of other key components, will be developed and demonstrated through two classes of stochastic processing networks: multiple pools of many-server systems and networks of single-server queues.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this NSF sponsored project, the PI and Anton Braverman at
Northwestern University have advanced Stein's method for steady-state
diffusion approximations of stochastic processing networks that model
many service systems including customer call centers and hospital
inpatient operations.

A major innovation from this research is to demonstrate that Stein's
method is an effective engineering tool to generate high-order
steady-state diffusion approximations.  These high-order
approximations were demonstrated to be universally accurate in that
they continue to be accurate across different system loads.  In a
hospital inpatient model, the high-order approximations allow quick
evaluation of the impact of bed-capacity and discharge timing on
patients waiting times for admission.

In addition to being an engineering tool, the Stein's method has been
used as a mathematical tool to prove error bounds of the proposed
approximations. These bounds quantify the maximum errors from
easy-to-compute approximations of true performance measures that are
either difficult or impossible to compute. For the Erlang-C model, it is proved that the high-order approximation indeed achieves a higher order convergence rate than the conventional approximation under both the Weisserstein distance metric and the Cramer-type moderate deviations metric.

Five former and current Cornell PhD students had been partially
supported from this NSF grant. Anton Braverman graduated in 2017 and
is currently an assistant professor at Northwester University. Aurora
Feng (female) graduated in 2020 and is currently a quantitative researcher at
Teza Technologies in Austin, Texas. Chang Cao is expected to graduate
in 2021. Mark Gluzman and Yaosheng Xu (female) are expected to
graduate in 2022.
